content:
ry 1, 2015
Does Diablo better than D3!As an avid fan of Diablo 1 and Diablo 2, I was sorely disappointed by the gameplay and support put forth by Blizzard into Diablo 3. My search for a new hack 'n' slash RPG that I could sink my teeth into began. After sinking countless hours into games like Titan Quest (which was never fully completed and released with many bugs. Still recommended though!) a couple of former Diablo developers went and made Torchlight. The first game was great: well balanced, fun, hours of replayability...but it lacked multiplayer.Torchlight 2 brings together all of the same great elements from the first release, and adds multiplayer and even more replayability with Steam Workshop's player created content! With four classes to choose from, multiple playthroughs, the ability to switch difficulty settings at any time, and high character leveling capabilities, you can literally spend weeks playing this game by yourself or with friends. My only complaint about this game is that the Embermage appears to be a bit overpowered (OP). However, if you're new to the Diablo-esque genre of hack 'n' slash, loot-♥♥♥♥♥ gaming then you may like the prospect of making things a bit easier on yourself in the early-game.Ratings out of 8 bits: 1 bit = low, 8 bits = high.Graphics: 8 bits. Although a bit dated by 2015 standards, the game's lush and colorful landscapes are almost as enticing as the myriad of color effects for spells and attacks. On many occassions I found myself snapping screenshots of exotic locales as if I were on vacation.Sound: 8 bits. Coupled with the beautiful graphics of Torchlight 2 is an amazing soundtrack of intrigue with intermittent cries of enemies as they shatter and explode.Story: 6 bits. Even though effort was put into this RPG to give it a compelling storyline, it felt forced and overused at times. The cutscenes were lower-budget than the gameplay, and, although using a different art style than Diablo, the story smacked of the Diablo storyline. Seeing the evil mage fleeing into the desert reminded me too much of the wanderer from Diablo 2 always moving East. I would have liked to have seen more of a unique storyline than just unique artwork for the cutscenes.Gameplay: 8 bits. Nothing to complain about here. Lots of unique areas to explore, dungeons to conquer, baddies to slay, and loot to horde!...with the excitement broken up by quiet fishing trips.Execution: 7 bits. Although this title brings together everythings Diablo and Torchlight fans have come to love, I can't help but feel that not enough was done to separate this title as different than Diablo 2. A few things have been changed, many improvements made, but for everything that was added it feels as if something was taken away. The ability to easily modify powerful items was added, but set items were nerfed to the point of uselessness. There are more examples, but I feel one is enough here.Overall: 8 bits. This game is a must-have for any RPG/Diabloesque gamer! Highly recommended for anyone with loads of time to spare, or someone who just wants to work their way through a fun hack 'n' slash with a great story!

content:
er 30, 2013
												Game: Torchlight 2Genre: RPG-AdventureDeveloper: Runic GamesSystem: PC (Steam)Total Score: 92/100Value Score: 9.2/10• Story: 7/10o Torchlight 2's storyline picks off where Torchlight 1 ended. The Alchemist which was one of the main characters from the first game ended up becoming corrupt thanks to the effects of the last game's villain's heart. Now you who will play as a new character will have to hunt him down and save the world from whatever he is planning to. You'll be going through several towns, dungeons and all sorts of terrain to find the Alchemist. The storyline overall is a bit generic but the side stories and side quests and their importance plays a interesting role within the overall game.• Characters: 7/10o Characters from the first game do appear in this game but barely do you interact with them, other than that all the enemies in the game and the characters you meet afterwards are all new but do not hold much substance like other RPGs however the amount of characters especially when it comes to enemy designs is quite huge. The player themselves can also create their own character, choosing the gender, skin color, hair appearance and color amongst other tidbits though you would not probably notice a difference due to the fact the armor you get in the game would make it to where you probably would not care about how you make your character look.• GamePlay: 10/10o Torchlight 2's gameplay is very similar to Torchlight 1's with a few new additions. For one, you have the choice to play as 4 different classes: Berserker which is best for close quarters combat and has insane speed, Mechanic is which best as a support character and as a secondary attacker, Outlander which is best with long range attacks and finally Ember Mage which is the equivalent of a Wizard in TL2 which is pretty much self explanatory. Depending on what you choose for skills and equipment you can build your character up to different builds and uses such as having a offensive ember mage instead of a magic user. The user interface is very similar to TL1 which is heavily inspired by Diablo and World of Warcraft. You have access to different features in towns and throughout different dungeons such as the ability to gamble for items, power up items through enchantments (which do not break or de-enchant anymore), to fuse items. Along with that the usual item shop, weapon/armor shop, and the special item/magic shop as well. There are a lot of side quests along with the story's main quests. One of the biggest additions to the game from its predecessor is Online Multiplayer, many people have anticipated this feature and wanted so much from the first game will now get to enjoy it in this game as up to 6 players can connect to each other on TL2's public servers or make their own private server via LAN. All items are exclusive to each player, no player will see another player's item or treasure (this is to prevent any disputes for loot).• Graphics: 10/10o Torchlight 2's graphical interfaces, environment and character sprites designs are similar to the first game but further improved with using current technologies making it one of the best looking 2Dish helicopter view games ever made.• Sound: 10/10o Torchlight 2 uses voiceovers throughout the majority of the game's main storyline, there will be instances where you will hear voices from other npcs and from yourself during dungeon raids. Torchlight 2's sound effects are both a combination of new effects to the game and uses some effects from the first game. The voiceovers are pretty well done for the characters and the sound effects go nicely with the environment and during the action sequences of cutscenes and battles.• Music: 8/10o Torchlight 2 uses similar style of music that the first game used, calm soothing orchestral type music is used mostly in the game, most of the parts of the game it has that unique Star Wars like epic feeling in the background whenever you travel the terrain or go through a town conversing with the NPCs. The developers were also kind enough to allow players to actually have access to the full OST of the game via the Game's folder on the PC, so enjoy the whole OST of Torchlight 2 on your portable mp3 player.• Length: 10/10o Torchlight 2's length is possibly its second greatest aspect if not the gameplay, the game's main storyline by itself should take you no more than 20 hours and additional 5-10 hours' worth of grinding and side questing on the side. If that isnt enough, you may do multiple playthroughs with friends or with other characters to see the world of Torchlight through different experiences which of course adds massive appealing value to this aspect.• Replay Value: 10/10o One of the best things about most western games is the replay value and TL2 is no exception. The Online multiplayer experience by itself adds great value to the replay value through different experiences and difficulties available for you to choose from. Once you finish the game, you get access to a endless random dungeon which takes you to random environments so you can explore thoroughly for additional treasures and other items. Along with that to add even more value, they added a New Game+ which allows you to play the game all over again using the same character but with a more difficulty twist to the gameplay.• Player Value: 10/10o Overall Torchlight 2 expands over the first one and improves in pretty much in every way, despite some network issues it may have from time to time, players will surely enjoy the multiplayer experiences and if not they can dabble on the single player experience which like the multiplayer can be experienced through different difficulties. You have a pretty decent customization options for your characters and can easily build up any class in any possible way. The graphical details have improved from the game, the sound effects and music are kept the similar to the first game. Pretty much TL2 consists of all the good aspects of TL1 plus more.

												One of the biggest problems with these Hack 'n Slash / Dungeon Crawler / Lootpocalypse games is the huge piles of loot that you (or at least I) feel compelled to lug back to town every five minutes of combat to sell. And where Dungeon Siege solved this problem with pack mules in singleplayer and ignored the problem in coop, and where Diablo 3 'solved' it by making all the junk loot worthless (people just like seeing lootsplosions, right? They don't like it for the money its worth, that would be silly!), the Torchlight games solved this with an awesome/adorable ferret with goggles that takes your unwanted gear back to town and sells it for you (and I guess they have other animals that can do the same thing or something).Besides solving the one flaw of the genre, Torchlight 2 does everything else right (or at least right enough): Online or LAN coop, ferrets with goggles, crazy explosive spell effects, ferrets with goggles, tons of cool loot, ferrets with goggles, random dungeon layouts and ferrets with goggles.As if all of that wasn't enough, they also have ferrets with goggles!

ry 14, 2013
An Underrated Action RPGRunic made huge improvements on the first installation of the series; it's a formidable ARPG in its own right. I got this around the same time as I bought Diablo 3 and ended up playing this way more. I always recommend playing online multiplayer games with friends but even playing with friends on D3 wasn't nearly as much fun. D3 gives off a gothic, eerie tone whereas Torchlight 2 has a lot more charm, the characters are memorable, and the game overall is much more simplistic. In this case, less is more. I also enjoyed doing the quests alone but it was still more engaging to play with friends.It has a Borderlands 2-like mechanic where you can play it again on an even more challenging difficulty with better loot. The story isn't very memorable but the soundtrack is good, the mechanics are fun, and there's plenty of whimsical moments. It's also got the best character customization I've seen in an ARPG with no terrible, stereotypical, and racist tropes like the Chinese wizard dragon lady *cough*Diablo 3*cough*! All the more reason to love this game. I strongly recommend playing this with friends.Be mindful of your skill allocation, especially if you're too lazy to get any mods. I had to start over because I messed up the first time.8/10

er 20, 2013
												My first gaming experience was given by an RPG, back then (1999), a curious 7 year old me didn't know that much about what it was or what it represented, but I liked it and wanted to know more and more about it...why does it die if I click on it ? why does stuff drop from it after it dies ? back then I thought most of them just go to sleep after they stop interacting with you, but after seeing the first blood pool I soon realized that wasn't the case. Growing up with the golden age of '90s cartoon from CN, you start to understand pretty quickly when something is what it is, and not something else, if it doesn't want to be something else that is. Back to the game, I came back to it again and again as the years passed, understanding more and more about it, until one day I got to finish it and said to myself, "this was nice, but is it the best ? ". A few more years passed and the first news of Torchlight started to appear in gaming magazines and online media, so of course I liked a reimagining of the first game that made me love gaming. This time though, we're talking about Torchlight 2, and how it improved on the initial formula, keeping the main cast from the first game, and making them a part of the story in T2. I personally love this game, and have played it quite a while before buying it on steam. I think everyone should have a go at this game, not because it's fun, not because it's cartoonish, not even because it's a great experience, but because it's that type of game that can really show you the amount of dedication the people who made it managed to put into something that you can't even hold in your hand; from the artwork, to the soundtrack, animations, and even the small things, like fishing and moving boards away to find loot, this game shows that true dedication isn't something only present in the first title, but something that can and is transmuted in time, from one game to the next. That and the fact that I can never get tired of seeing my panda pet get on two legs and start fisticuffing from the largest to the smallest enemy. :)Also the modding community did a great job making the game more diverse and fitting to the likes of everyone.In the end, my initial review for Torchlight 2 still stands, but I just felt like some back story would make it more recognizable to some of you gamers that are like me, and enjoy playing a game that shows of the dedication of some amazing people. So to conclude, T2, great RPG experience form the creators of Diablo 1 and 2. :)

content:
, 2014
												I remember the day when I had bought this game when it was on a Steam sale. I had a couple of dollars left and I wanted to spend the money on something that interested me. I had bought Torchlight II and haven't touched it for quite some time, since I was not an active Steam user back then. When I first played it, I immediately regretted not playing this sooner.Torchlight II is, to put in the simplest words, an amazing game. The product is a highly polished game with many surprises hidden around every corner.  The world is randomly generated every time you start a new character/start New Game+ on an existing character so every experience will be a highly unique one. The game really gets to the point; you can immediately delve into the fun of clicking on monsters and annihilating them with your weapons/skills.As is said in many other reviews, the story is definitely lacking. I had attempted to follow the story when I first started playing but ended up not caring for the story at all. If you are into an RPG with a rich story, this game is not for you.Gameplay-wise, this game tops it all. You'll be mashing your number hotkeys and your mouse trying to rid of the monsters trying to swarm you. There are many random traps and surprises lurking in every dungeon and area you face. The skills for each character are also special and will leave you wanting to upgrade all your skills. As said before, each dungeon and area is randomly generated, providing a unique experience everytime you play. You will feel a great sense of accomplishment as you finally knock out the final boss of the game. This then leads to the Mapworks, which you can buy with your in-game currency and play special dungeons. Or you can start up NG+ and start your whole adventure again, keep all your character stats but buffing all item drops and monsters.All in all, Torchlight II is definitely a game that anyone should check out, even if you do not like RPGs. This game is a must-have on anyone's game list.

												Torchlight II is truly a great ARPG.  The base game contains hundreds of hours of game play.  Then there are challenges galore to seek! You can alter the game into any fashion that you want.  Want to try a full set of badass armor?  You can enable it.  Want more maps?  It's there!  Want a pet that's not in the base game?  There's a mod for it.  Hell you can create it if you like!  This is truly a great game that should be in your Steam Library.  It has way more content than Diablo 3 developers could dream of in a thousand years because of the dedicated modders out there.  And it all runs seamlessly without bugs.  The code for this game is airtight!What are you waiting for?  Get Torchlight II today!

												Torchlight II is a really good game, but not a great game. It has an endearing art-style that's easy on the eyes, and the gameplay is addictive enough to keep you playing 'till the end (I played about 50 hours by the time I beat it). However, there is nothing about this game that is exceptional or raises the bar. The story isn't deep or engaging, and the world lacks depth. Had the developers expanded the towns and added sub characters to strengthen the plot, then this game could have been a bench mark. The loot drops are well-balanced and look decent, the world is visually appealing, even interesting in some places, and the monsters are well-designed. But beyond the relentless grind, there's nothing much motivating you to keep collecting and throwing away loot 'till the next boss fight, except more loot and boss fights, that is. If you're just looking for a game to help you pass the time without being bored, then it does its job well, but don't expect an engaging story to justify the 50+ hours you may waste playing it. In the end, I feel like I got my money's worth, but only based on what I already kind of expected.

												It is inevitable to compare this game to Blizzard's hack 'n slash RPG. I would say this would be the poor-man's version of Diablo III, but the truth of the matter is Torchlight II holds it's ground and could even be considered a better game overall, depending on what you're looking for.Torchlight II brings better loot, better progressions system, mob variety and arguably a better 'end-game'. The only two thing it lacks, compared to Diablo III, is the graphical fidelity (although since the game is done in a cartoonish art-style, it is not immediately noticable) and story.While Torchlight II manages to win points in the atmosphere department, the story of the Diablo universe offers a much more expanded lore and world to explore. Voice acting, cinematics and sound design are far better than what Torchlight II has. Which is to be expected from a series that started it's roots in indie gaming. Experience sharing in multiplayer could use some tweaking, but loot is instanced for every player and trading is fully functional for all items you find. A big plus for the game is also mod support, something which Diablo III lacks. The Steam Workshop is sure to increase the life-span of the game, and enchance the experience according to your taste buds.Despite some of it's shortcomings, it is still one of the better hack 'n slash RPGs out there. Definitely worth your time!

y 28, 2014
												I will echo many other reviews and start by saying: If you liked Diablo 2, you should really enjoy Torchlight 2.In fact, at times I felt this game was almost too derivative. Both games have 4 Acts. Each Act has its own hub town, bosses, unique geographic setting and a narrated cinematic at each Act's beginning. Even the storyline has a lot of similarities. With all that said, Torchlight 2 clearly wasn't designed to be novel. Instead they set out to do the dungeon crawler genre really, really well. And they succeeded.The gameplay is fast paced, addictive, loot filled fun. Everything about this game is user friendly. It's easy to get to and from town; your pet can easily be sent to sell off your unwanted spoils while you keep adventuring; even playing on the Veteran difficulty I almost never had to buy potions or magic scrolls; quests are clearly marked on the map, never leaving you wondering what to do next; when you die you have the option to respawn in town for free or lose gold but respawn near where you died.My main criticism is likely to be experienced differently by each person who plays Torchlight 2. I started to get bored with the game about 3/4ths through the story mode. This is common for me with games of this type. I should note that I played to the end of the game fully in single player. Your mileage may vary particularly if you plan to play online with friends.I'll close by saying if you did NOT like Diablo 2, or other highly rated dungeon crawlers, do not be swayed by all the positive reviews this game has gotten. Trust your gut; I suspect that the type of person that will enjoy this game already knows that they will enjoy it.

er 7, 2013
												Torchlight II reminds me of a couple of other typical "looter" games such as "Diablo" or the latest F2P game "Path of Exile". However, a few features ultimately standout from these other games which is why I highly recommend this game over the others. First, you do not have to be a diehard gamer in order to play this game. There are 4 difficulty tiers, and even the second tier (normal) feels relatively easy to an experienced player, even if you have never played another looter-type game. Second, since it is mainly a point-and-click-RPG game, one may believe they would get tired of the game after but a few moments. This is hardly the case as all the little features and nuances work beautifully together to bring you an experience that is immediately rewarding and highly addictive unlike other alternatives. Lastly, while it is a relatively fast-paced game, it seems to be more manageable in the gameplay department across the board for any player in comparison to what I have seen from Path of Exile. This just further demonstrates that just because it is free, does not mean that is better for you in the long run. Oh, and the best part is...I've only been talking about the single player experience. This game also possesses a co-op feature so you can play through the story with several friends, or even random strangers. Player trading is also included, so expect hours to pass by if you play this game with people you enjoy being around and love killing creatures with them. Now Torchlight II does have a few odd in-game features to it I've noticed. For one, the blood animations do not seem even remotely realistic (even by fantasy standards). You could kill an enemy and they would first explode followed by the entire wall being entirely covered in blood...which the wall could be 10 times your size and your enemy's size, so this makes absolutely no sense. Also, the enemies sometimes get stuck in the most random places, which allows you to easily snipe them and pick away at their health continuously if you like utilizing a ranged character and those style tactics. I've already done this with a few mini-bosses and laughed all the while. Lastly, I honestly wish I did not have to click for every attack. I wish there was some auto-attack feature after you have targeted an enemy, but this is just me being nit-picky at this point. If you notice, these are just minor issues as well. I have seen no major problems or adversities to mention from this game so far as you can plainly see as well.Ultimately, Torchlight II provides a unique, personalized, open world experience which gives games such as the Diablo series a run for its money, especially when it is on sale in the steam store. I highly recommend picking this game up when it is on sale, as you will not be disappointed with the many hours you will invest into this game alone or with friends. Now, excuse me as I go bandage up my index finger for the next extensive click-fest that I am about to perform in this game.

What Is Torchlight II?Torchlight II is one of those wildly popular Steam games which hardly requires any introduction for fans of isometric-style action RPG's. Developed by Runic Games in 2012 as a more polished and refined version of its previous incarnation (Torchlight), it is widely hailed and beloved by scores of fanatical gamers (well over 3 million+) for its many favorable similarities to the equally popular Diablo series.The true hallmark of this title however, is that the sprawling world it offers to you on a very reasonably priced silver platter is a gorgeously inviting one awaiting to be explored to its fullest....tempting you with countless secrets to uncover & treasures to collect. In fact there is more loot to be found hidden within its myriad of locations than you could possibly wrap your mind around. It's easily one of those gems with which you can sink hundreds of hours into, since it offers level randomization for enhanced replayability inside of its open world system...one which includes weather as well as day/night cycles incidentally.GameplayFeaturing a very tight local + online co-op mode (in addition to solo offline play), you'll soon notice that you will be introduced to a diverse bounty of seemingly never-ending quests & side-quests given to you by those who require your assistance in one way or another. And fortunately, you'll have a ferocious pet by your side to help out in battle as needed, one who even possesses its own inventory!  In addition to the exploration and loot collecting, your primary objective will be to battle against a wide assortment of variously menacing monsters as you gradually level up your character with more skills, gold, and gear during this compelling campaign. Action is very fluid, brisk, and energetic...with a satisfying number of both weapon upgrades and weapon types (including melee & guns) to keep you more than entertained.Both your mana (ie. energy) and health bars will be depleted during combat, and must be replenished as necessary with collected vials which can be used up at any time.Character customization is present, although somewhat limited and basic in scope I felt. It's probably the most glaring aspect of the game which could have been improved further still. Nonetheless, it is still present at least, and you'll have your choice of either male/female characters spread across 4 distinct classes: Embermage, Outlander, Berserker, Engineer.Level design was quite impressive & varied in an overall sense, with some specific areas like the dungeons being especially atmospheric. It was quite a joy for me to explore every single nook & cranny of each individual section traversed as I hunted around for items to collect between waves of enemies....who themselves were sufficiently unique enough throughout the campaign so as to not feel repetitious in any way.There is just so very much to do in the game, and even after investing a few quality hours into it, there was an undeniable feeling that I've still only barely scratched the surface as to what awaits me further into its story.GraphicsWhat I especially appreciated about the presentation, is that this world is surprisingly vibrant in color as opposed to being dreary & muted looking in appearance as some other such similar games are. Which is then reinforced furthermore by the distinctly cartoon-style graphics found here. This in turn is all neatly tied together by a very well-done lighting system which somehow breathes a sense of intriguing realism into this magical place. All in all, it is quite pleasant on the eyes and sports a unique charm to it. And best of all, there are an ample number of graphics options available for fine-tuning your display preferences.AudioVoice acting was definitely above par, and sounded quite slick for the many varied characters present. (Although at times I felt that your character's obsession with his depleted mana levels was a bit overly-repetitive!). Whereas music itself was mellow & symphonic in nature...wonderfully balancing out the mood of each particular scene in an appropriate manner. And finally, sound effects were more than adequate in accomplishing their task of enhancing immersion...especially so with delightful effects such as thunder reverberating through the rainy night, for example. Steamified?It fully is, and includes both trading cards and a whopping 119 achievements to be unlocked.DLCNone available.ModsThe vast collection of available mods via the Steam Workshop is where this game truly shines like no other. There are literally hundreds of them to choose from in every possible category imaginable, and quite honestly you could find pretty much anything your little heart desires here.Verdict - 9/10Torchlight II has to be one of the best values out there in ARPG's...because while it only costs a fraction of what its pricier triple-A competitors do, it nonetheless very much competes as one, and more importantly, feels like one with its overhauled & redesigned user-interface which was a breeze to use. Accessibility is fantastic here as well, showcasing a streamlined and mostly straight-forward character leveling system which I greatly appreciated. Because being hopelessly confused inside of skill trees is not my personal idea of a fun time, and here, they most certainly get it right in steering the focus onto actual gameplay instead. And along with its multiple difficulty settings, just about anyone can enjoy what it has to offer...from the very casual side of the spectrum for those who simply wish to explore its scenery, all the way up to the no-nonsense hardcore setting for those veterans out there who wish to master its more subtle nuances. All in all, Torchlight II has underwent quite a lot of refinement to date, and runs at fantastic framerates even on less than cutting-edge hardware. But most of all, this is an exciting world to step inside of and one which you can very much have a great time with since there is always something interesting to do along with an accompanying sense of accomplishment felt as each goal is successfully completed...and that is why...I'll gladly rate this one a 9/10Pros:- Many hours of fun with lots to do and much to explore- Impressively designed & vast isometric world with vibrantly colorful aesthetics- Wonderfully implemented dynamic zoom camera- Nice selection of weapons + gear- Can play as both male or female- Great value for the purchase price- Rebindable keys- Impressive amount of adjustable graphics options- Local/online co-op + offline single-player - Steam achievements + trading cards- Countless mods available via the Steam WorkshopCons:- Character customization system could be more robust- Some of the character speech is repeated a bit too often For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com

												*This review will be downvoted to hell by fans*Summary:Torchlight II clings to its Diablo series heritage like no other. It tries to be, at the same time, both fresh and familiar to fans of the genre. In the end, It’s just a cartoony Diablo II clone with elaborated gameplay mechanics. Both gives a mixture that seems appetizing but in reality is just stale and plain boring.6/10The Good :- Many, many weapons and items- Pets- Overally polished- Good musicThe Bad :- Very repetitive gameplay, even for hack'n'slash- Bland atmosphere and plot- Feels like cartoony clone of Diablo II- Dated graphicsI did not finish the game. My review follows these situations rarely. Even more rarely, I’m struggling to like something. This time, it’s Torchlight II.As serious as I can be, this fight ensued the moment I started the game and ceased when it ended up in a virtual dump. Don’t get me wrong, I adore hack’n’slash RPG’s.I absolutely loved Diablo I and more so, Diablo II. First part created the genre with gloomy atmosphere and revolutionary gameplay. The sequel had the magic to keep you clicking so many times, one would believe you’re testing mouse manufacturer’s claims of billion click durability. Torchlight II has neither. And here’s why.Right of the bat, Torchlight II shows resemblance to Diablo II. Made by the same author, the music is unmistakable. At first, I was glad because I really enjoy these notes but at the same time it prevents Torchlight to be unique. Several sounds, like opening a teleport, are basically cloned from Diablo II. Even the sequence of worlds and it’s hubs in TL are the same as Diablo II – wilderness, desert, dense forest, hell. And just like in Diablo II, our nemesis is a mysterious traveler that we’re always one step behind from. All of this takes away from Torchlight II. It’s just too familiar to call it a world of its own. It’s a copy with cartoony overlay which makes it neither dark and gloomy, nor light-hearted.As years passed, hack’n’slash games had to mutate it’s formula to remain fresh and attractive to gamers. Happily, Torchlight II has some tweaks and non-standard ideas, one of which is company of your pet. Essentialy, it’s your coop friend. There are several pets to choose from, all of which can pick and store items for you, wear accessories, fight, cast spells and last but totally not list, do a little shoppin while you bash evil’s head. You can also fish for, well, fishes that for reasons unknown, can transform your pet into a killing beast.As It goes for Diablo clones, you have a lot to choose from to do that. Beside leveling, getting a good equipment is the core element of action RPG’s. Torchlight II gives you –collecting sets, enchanting, socketing and putting in gems. Unfortunately, beside collecting and buying spells that can be used by any class, I can’t find anything that discerns Torchlight from other ARPG’s. Speaking of classes, I didn’t play every class. I focused mainly on Engineer. What I found out, is that I played through majority of the game using only 4 out of dozens. I’ve tried more variety but I’ve always ended up coming back to previous skills as they work best. So it all came down to getting the right equipment. Though you’ll encounter or buy many, many stuff it’s not that easy to find an upgrade. I’ve completed 3/4 of the game using just 3 ranged weapons with a single tactic. Single tactic, because even though monsters seem to vary much, the’re all killed the same. On hard difficulty I didn’t though that Tourchlight II is challenging, not even for a wihle)That said, it was hard to not get bored. Accompanied by generic maps, plot that isn’t worth mentioning (which I won’t) and repetitiveness with no challenge, I was struck with remorse while playing Torchlight II. Remorse that told me, that time with Torchlight II could be spent way better or at least on a superior game. Torchlight II is an OK ARPG, that excels in mediocrity. If ARPG’s are your thing, you could bite the bullet, especially that it’s dirt cheap now, but don’t say that I didn’t warn you.

content:
ry 28, 2016
												Torchlight's actual storyline and most major quests can be completed in ~15-20 hours. However, the extra content that takes more grinding is the real meat of this game. Acquiring end-game loot to make yourself a raidboss is the final destination. My experience with this game is that at first it's quite disorienting, however with more gameplay it gets better, but also becomes very robotic . I do like the graphics and the storyline of the game as well as the variety of different settings and monsters you face. However, if you don't like grinding this game may not be for you. I would recommend this game if it's on sale, but if it were bought for full price I don't think it's worth it.I like the fact that you can Co-op, however in co-op worlds the max amount of players is 4 and whatever you accomplish in that co-op world isn't translated over to your singleplayer, so it's best to keep quests finished in singleplayer first. My impression of the community is that there's a bunch of super dedicated players and keep to themselves a lot and if you're not dedicated you can't break the ice with them. Another awesome feature is that the workshop really brings out a whole new environment for the game. Extra classes, extra abilities,the workshops are a must visit if you want to experience this game fully.Some downsides do include that the combat interface/system isn't explained at first and you're just dropped in a place and you're expected to know how to fight. Maybe a tutorial at first wouldn't hurt. With this being said, the learning curve isn't actually that great if you've played any RPG before. There are 4 basic stats each helping a certain feature and beneficial for certain classes.In summary, I think this game has some great features, the main storyline replayability isn't that high, but the workshops and the extra after the storyline quest grinding will be what you spend most of your time on. I rate this game a good 8/10 for $5.49, maybe lower if it's going for $21.99.

												I've not played a hack and slash rpg for a long time and had felt the itch recently. 34 hours later and I think the itch is scratched for now.Torchlight 2 is a fantastic game if you have fond memories of Diablo 2 and in a lot of way it is a superior game. It is very streamlined and well paced,  the soundtrack is really atmospheric and the skills system was fun for me as a Berserker, having had the most fun in D2 with the Assassin.It is so much more polished, but that is sort of what I think kind of detracts from the game. The economy is so tight, that money was always a concern even in the late game. It makes purchases even later mean much more, but I just didn't like that aspect of the game.The way set items and uniques are distributed also never felt as satisfying as I think they should have. This might be me misremembering how it was in D2, but a lot of uniques were not as good as just some random enchanted items.Lastly this is the first time where I have skipped the story entirely. I got the gist that there's guardians and an alchemist and a netherlord, but from the opening cinematic I was not hooked. The simply shaded cartoony style just didn't click with me at all. I almost feel like a Warcraft 3 in game cinematic might have been better.Despite those things, I recommend this game to fans of the genre and newcomers. I think they did a good job of streamlining the formula, but I kind of missed some of the broken tropes of it's predescessors.

												Every once in a while, I love to smash everything and everyone in sight - then I turn to a something like Torchlight II. Hack & Slay is the name of the game, and it feels just as satisfying as the rich booty from those battles. The enemies and surroundings are diverse enough, and some bosses look relatively awesome. I say "relatively" because overall, the graphics have not aged well. On the other hand, the music is still excellent. Dialogues are short and do not involve any important decisions or moral dilemmas, which is an advantage because the voice acting is mostly sub-par. Grim Dawn is superior in this regard and managed to create a lot more depth of atmosphere (e.g. the Steampunk setting with fireweapons side by side with swords and maces is more plausible in a post-apocalyptic scenario - Torchlight does not bother with giving you that kind of background). Also, it is four years younger and has better graphics. If in doubt which one you should play, I would prefer Grim Dawn. Nevertheless, Torchlight II is well done, it offers consistently engaging gameplay and character progression as well as several options for you to keep on playing after finishing the main story. The feature that you can use your pet as a connection to town markets is not realistic, but innovative and conveniently saves your hero some annoyingly repetitive errands, which is why I make this honorary mention here. I recommend this game to fans of the genre and give it a 7/10 in this comparison group.

content:
4, 2013
												Torchlight II is easily one of the best Action RPGs that you can play right now and that has been released in recent years. It also happens to be one of my all-time favorite games. With the FREE play event going on now through Sunday 1PM PST, you owe it to yourself to play this great Runic game and see why its so highly rated. One awesome feature is that you can play this game in Offline Mode, a great way to pass time when having internet issues. It contains great character classes, very fun skills to use, and so much shiny loot to pick up that your head will explode. Also don't forget about the fishing. :)It just gets better with the addition of Steam Workshop now that there is a great amount of content that has been converted and updated using this format. While it does suck that you can only run the game with a total of ten active mods, you can have steam workshop track and auto-update fifty mods in total.Thankfully, skilled users have become quite successful at releasing compilations that help bypass this limit and enhance your gaming experience with lots of active mods such as the fantastic work done by Bandit in his "Combine Them All" mod. :)Another great feature Runic added is that the game separates your original-stock and workshop-mod characters into different save folders and cloud saves. This makes it very easy for you to play your high level stock characters online with others for those purist out there. Then you restart your game in mod mode and play with your friends online using your modded characters. If you're modded toons are like mine, they will be custom classes such as "Necromancer" and "Warlock" from the SynergiesMOD by Salan or "Ninja" and "Ronin" from the Far East Pack by Zyph.I can recommend a nice list of workshop mods that play very well together and enhance your game even further once you have beaten the standard version of the game. It's what I use when playing online or offline to help me relax, unwind, and clear my head from design fatigue. One of these days I'll get around to posting them as a Collection in the Steam Workshop when I have more free-time between designing games. TIP: I highly recommend that if you play modded games on-line with your friends that you synch your game mods and the order they are loaded beforehand to eliminate most on-line problems. The easiest way we found to do this was share a zip file of all the mods we would use with a text file listing the mods priority when loading them if anybody joining didn't have them. We would not include large and popular mods such as SynergiesMOD, Far East Pack, and Enhanced Retex, but we would note the version number in the text file. There are a few mods that don't work well together or on-line, but we've been able to play the majority of them in different combinations as long as we followed this tip.TIP: While the Steam Cloud synch tends to do a good job overall, sometimes it can fail and override your local copy of your saved game with an outdated one from the Steam Cloud. What I've done is keep a secondary backup of my saved games so when that happens, I can easily replace the cloud copy with my current local backup. The default location for the Torchlight II saved games is at "My Documents\My Games\Runic Games\Torchlight 2\". You want to backup the "save" and "modsave" folders regularly especially if you play the game frequently in offline mode.Hopefully someday we will get a remastered HD version of the game but I will settle for Torchlight III. =)

												You can't talk about Torchlight 2 without talking about Diablo 3, and I can't talk about Diablo 3 without feeling morose and amused. Blizzard have developed a lot of my favourite video games, though they are not the developer that I once loved. Diablo 3's release was a joke and shows the folly of imposing always online in a game that does not need it. I find it worrying that Blizzard, Activion Blizzard now I suppose, are helping set this precedent of very heavy handed DRM.Torchlight 2 is fun, cheap, can be played in offline mode and has a lan mode. I like that hoarding ember has been discouraged in the game and I like all of the classes. It was pretty silly that I had to use autohotkey in Torchlight as key bindings for abilities could not be changed but thankfully this is different in Torchlight 2. Mod support has vastly increased the life of the game for me. I've not even progressed past the second area as I've spent so much time playing around with community created classes and such in hardcore mode.I'd reccommend purchasing and playing this video game, especially when it is on sale for <£10.

												WARNING- I have only played up to part way through act 2 of this game, but I have experience with all classes. I have not played the multiplayer.If you like ARPGs, you have probably already bought this game, so do not need to to recommend it to you. I don't. For what it's worth, Torchlight II is much better than it's predecessor, consisting of better, meatier combat as well as multiplayer and better difficulty. As an ARPG, it is near perfection, but as a game I find it somewhat lacking. Weapons like the shotgun and cannon could be meatier, and fighting with a melee character seems to lack impact. The game attempts to seem open world, but considering that I would have to clear out every area simply to keep up with levels, it misses the point entirely. In my opinion, the point of open world is that things are OPTIONAL- you could explore the nearby cave, or you could not. Removing that basically makes the concept useless. Mobility is done well, with dodging a powerful blow feeling very satisfying and fun, however there are some attacks that simply curve around to hit me again, removing the satisfaction. Bosses are similarly very satisfying, but also very dangerous and difficult to avoid- with a great feeling when you beat them.The skill system is not innovative, but generally well done- nothing more to say here. The dark music provides an interesting contrast to the cartoony art style, but I feel that the story simply isnt dark enough to fully support that contrast. However, most of the problems mentioned before are nitpicking, and the main game is stellar for its genre.If you like ARPGs, you will love this game, but it wont turn you onto the genre if you hate them.

content:
y 6, 2014
												Everything and more!Torchlight was one of the best hack and slash RPG's to come out between the release of Diablo II and Diablo III. It had us turning our head, if even for a short time, and (if your a fan) rejuvenated our love of the genre with its colorful graphic's, epic loot, and random dungeon generator. While it was fairly generic it hit all the right notes, and except for multiplayer, was the perfect game to play till the release of Diablo III. Then Diablo III released....... Well while some did enjoy it, LOT's of players hated it (not a fan myself) and quickly Torchlight's predecessor was to the rescue.Now with a full multiplayer mode, modding capability, and overall improvements to the gameplay, Torchlight II is a fantastic sequel to the colorful h&s RPG from a few years ago. However there are some problems. Multiplayer is great to have if you want to play with friends, or have a small group on the net that regularly play. However if you expect the multiplayer to be as fully featured as games like Diablo III, Path of Exile, or hell even Diablo II you may be hard pressed. Its pretty much just a list of people playing and if you want to play with them you can, however most games are locked with a password and the games that do have people playing don't allow you to chat with them or anything before joining to find out what there doing. In fact you can only chat in game which kinda sucks if you want to set up quick runs or do any kind trading. As of late the multiplayer is pretty much dead. Overall I have to say that Torchlight II's multiplayer is not going to be the biggest draw for most fans of the genre. If you play games like Path of Exile or Diablo III for multiplayer Torchlight II may not be for you.However the overall improvements to the gameplay overshadow some of the multiplayer woes. Simple little improvements and details are what make Torchlight II's gameplay different from other's in the genre. While it will feel familiar to anyone who has played a h&s RPG, things like being able to equip not only a sword but dual wield it with a gun or any other single handed weapon give you the need to experiment with you character. Other things like your pet, make life a little easier for your dungeon crawling hero. Your pet can buy items in town, sell loot you find in dungeons, provide extra storage, and even help you in combat. You can also choose what pet you would like (including a freaking headcrab!).But the crowing achievement of Torchlight II is its just downright fun gameplay. You will never run out of things to do in Torchlight, Literally. While the games story is fairly generic (pretty much taken straight from Diablo II) the colorful environments epic enemies, fun boss fight, and funny cameos and homages make Torchlight II's story campaign all the more worth it. What most will love however is what you unlock after beating the game. You can just go ahead and do a (New Game +) which allows you to start the game over at your current level and fight tougher enemies throughout. Or you can decide to stay in the Mapworks which is the final hub world. It has all you need with every type of shop and merchant and one particular merchant that gives you random dungeons to buy. You can play these dungeons pretty much forever collecting loot and fighting bosses. This give Torchlight infinite playablity. Modding is also a big part of Torchlight II. Some people have already created epic mods that act as entire expansions to the game giving you plenty of more hours of gameplay. Modders have also fixed some of the issues with the game like, not being able to re-spec your character at will. While I have not done really any modding I am looking forward to playing some mods later on.Overall Torchlight II is well worth the 20$ price tag (oh did I forget to mention it's only 20$). Its somewhat lacking multiplayer cant overshadow the excellent hack and slash gameplay. If your like me and mostly play these kind of games for the singleplayer, you owe it to yourself to buy this game. At least give it a chance and get it when its like 5 bucks, trust me its worth it.Thanks for reading!

content:

												Crowborn's Review of Torchlight II-Ever since I was a boy, and got my hands on Diablo 1, I have been a fan of the hack-n-slash game-genre. Something about the game strung a cord inside of me, and I played it almost non-stop for years. Same with the sequel - it kept me busy through highschool and sane in the awkward years following when I was rampaging through life, trying to figure out what the 'eck I wanted to do. And so arrived the highly anticipated 3rd installment of the Diablo genre - to lackluster reviews. I picked it up immediately of course, but I were never able to enjoy it. It just seemed off to me, seemed strange, like an orange growing on an apple-tree, trying to fit in with the smooth green skinned fellas around it. But for me it failed at the deceit, and I put down the game after playing it for only a few months. Dissapointed and bereft of one of my favourite genres, I started looking around for substitutes. That's when I heard about Torchlight II.I had noticed the series before, but for some reason never gotten around to trying it out. It was supposed to be a fairly good diablo-clone, and while I liked the genre, it wasn't until one of my dear steam-friends gifted me the game, that I actually managed to sit down and play it. I felt obliged to, so to say. And my were I pleasantly surprised!Torchlight II is a really well made game. From the steam-punkish world, cross the interesting skill-sets, to the actio-packed maps - this game just breathes fun game design. Granted, the game is 'very' much a Diablo-clone, and anyone who ever played those games will immediately find everything intimately familiar. But that's not a bad thing. In fact, I find it darned good. I didn't have to read a bible of game-guides before daring to venture out in the the world of Torchlight, and hack and slash my way through the first pack of monsters I came across. It granted me immediate satisfaction and loads of fun.It feels to me like the devs of this game did right, what the guys at Blizz did wrong. Torchlight II follows to a point the tried and true old recipe of hack-n-slash. They don't try to reinvent or alter the genre, but instead stick to what works and 'has' worked for the last two decades. You got your attribute-points, your skill-points, random loot, runes and enchantments to upgrade your gear, rewarding exploration, and a story-line that doesn't distract you from your dungeon-delving fun.The game hearkens back to the good old days, and gives the players exactly what they expected - and a little more. It deserves a top grade, but due to an at times non-transparent stat-system and unbalanced characters, I have to subtract a few points. I give it:8.5/10

4, 2013
												I would like to preface this by noting that I have not played Torchlight 1. Due to the fairly close release dates, comparisons to Diablo 3 are inevitable.Torchlight 2 is basically Diablo 2 with more kiddy/cartoony 3D graphics. The game uses a fairly similar skill tree system to D2. For better or worse, investing points become permanent, so you'd best be committed to a build. Fortunately there are some mods that enable one to redo choices without triggering the cheating flag, but it's still something I'd rather avoid altogether. Meanwhile Diablo 3 allows you to 'respec' at will, which to be honest, is quite nice.I dabbled in all the classes, but I mostly played the Engineer and the Archmage. The class balance isn't too bad, but on higher difficulty levels, I'm not sure how one is expected to survive as a melee character. I even tried pure Vitality builds, and monsters still whack you down fast. In D3 melee characters are surprisingly sturdy.Leveling speed is pretty good. Every time I start a character it feels like I'm blowing through levels. Even in D3 with an exp gem in the helm, a Hellfire Ring and 10 Monster Power, leveling doesn't feel as fast as T2.Multiplayer T2 has been... iffy. Even months after release, I found desyncs happen, even with their servers being far less crowded. Somehow Diablo 3 manages to be playable despite all the nonsense that goes on the screen.I'm sad that Torchlight 2 had very little story. I was expecting this grand quest of discovery, only to be met with staple busy work. The quests were largely "kill monster, get reward." Heck, I already forgot what the game was about. Even if it's not the point of the game, I'd still like more compelling reasons to play.When you reach the end, you get to play New Game Plus, which mainly just ups the level of game and you retain everything. To be honest, this did not interest me at all. D3's approach is to go with an extra 100 bonus character levels, which also is not appealing.The verdict? If you had to choose I'd have to say Diablo 3 is the superior game, especially if you can get it on one of their 50% off sales. D3 offers more classes, considerably more spells, better graphics, sound, story, even replay. Biggest downsides are the 10 character limit and permanent online status.

												Torchlight II is cheap, fun, and addicting what's not to love about that?+ Beautiful Visuals: Torchlight II probably offers one of the most broad color palettes of any game ever with maybe the exception of Borderlands 2, the visuals are simple yet beautiful and stand apart from most other games in their own way.+ Wonderful loot system: Being a huge fan of ARPGs (Diablo in particular) I can't help but love any game mechanic that showers me with items whenever I make something explode, this is a game that makes you work hard for those hard to find items but when you finally get them it makes it all worth it.+ Multiplayer: The multiplayer in Torchlight is wonderful and features a drop in drop out system so regardless of what level or what part of the campaign you're playing you can join your friends at any time. The game's single player is fun so throw in three buddies (Seven friends with a mod) and it's a blast a little hectic but still alot of fun.+ Accessable difficulty: I personally hate games being overly difficult that's just my personal opinion, I don't play games to be frustrated I play games to have fun so I was quite pleased when I found out that Torchlight has multiple difficulties ranging all the way from easy to rediculous there's something for everyone.+ System requirements: PC has a TON of great games, running all of them is a different story and the variety of great games with low system requirements grows smaller by the day it's nice that a game that is as much fun as Torchlight is can be enjoyed by pretty much anyone with a PC.+ Mods: Since it's release Steam has opened the Steam Workshop to it which has infinitely expanded it's gameplay it's options at this point are rather limitless.- Visually messy multiplayer: I personally don't have this problem but I've read about people complaining that multiplayer becomes visually 'messy' with multiple players so it's something to keep in mind if you're buying this to play with other people.- Sometimes loot drops feel slightly disproportionate: Sometimes it feels like loot drops from average enemies are just as lucrative as boss loot drops.- Story is pretty weak: Not that Torchlight is known for it's outstanding story but yeah it's pretty weak here.Torchlight is a wonderful bargain and overall an enjoyable experience that I suggest everyone try at least once.8.5/10Reasonable Price Point: This game has been a bargain since day one and it has a wonderful development team I would say at least $30 USD.

												Like a lot of people, I found myself constantly going back to Diablo 2 and replaying it. Hours of clicking away at monsters, building characters, etc. This managed to re-capture a lot of that fun for me. The game does have a cartoonish art style which may turn off some but definitely doesn't detract from the game. I found the story to be fun and was happy when I completed it. It took me around 30ish hours or so to complete, but I do explore as much as possible and kill as many monsters as possible. The character classes all have 3 different skill trees to build out. I played through with the engineer (support, utility) myself. There is also the berszerker (warrior), outlander (ranger), embermage (caster). If you check out some of the stuff on steam works, you can also get additional classes through mods. End game you get the option to start over via New Game + (ala Chrono Trigger) where the game scales to a level range based on your level. They also have the mapworks option where you purchase maps from a vendor (with gold in game) which can be fun and have various buffs/debuffs to them. On top of that, this game still supports both internet and LAN play which is great. Definitely a solid buy for the price.

content:
ry 12, 2014
												So far, my time with Torchlight II has been great. The system requirements are not high so I can run it rather easily, which is rare for me nowadays. There are also a lot of mods for it which can really change the game to your liking; for instance, if there are new things you want in the game or things you simply don't like and want to remove, you can do that. This game could be even more fun if you play it with your friends. However, like most "Diablo-esque" games, it gets repetitive, but much like Borderlands 2, the loot keeps you coming back for more. Something TL2 lacks though is an engaging story, so unlike Borderlands 2, the loot and online multiplayer are really the ONLY things that make you ignore the repetitious combat (i.e. 80-90% of the game, if not more); where as in Borderlands 2 the story was at the very least funny with loveable characters, the story in Torchlight II feels like a formality. The characters are just there so it isn't a game where you literally just run around and kill stuff. The story is similar to any average MMO storyline, if not worse. And while the voice overs from the main quest NPCs are a nice touch, the story is honestly not good enough for me to care about what they have to say.That said, Torchlight II has great character growth. Not only do you notice your character's strength increase, but you can build your character in many different ways. Each class has 3 unique skill "pages" (They aren't really trees because you're pretty much free to spec into any skill provided you have the appropriate level), each with a bunch of abilities both passive and active, all of them interesting. My one nitpick with this is that not all skills are available to put skill points into from the get go. You must level up to unlock your skills. I suppose this is kind of the incentive to respec your character later on in the game, but I guess I'm lazy and don't like that idea. Hue.The combat system is nothing super amazing, it's pretty much faceroll keyboard smashing with little rhyme or reason. After all, the difficulty is strangely low for this kind of game. Maybe it's not fair to say that purely based on what I've heard about some difficulty levels in Diablo, but in my 13 hours playing this game, I have not died; even when I played the top tier of difficulty (not hardcore mode).Pros:-LOOT, BABY! LOTS O' LOOT!-Variety of weapon types and weapon sub-types-Medium replay value -Good character progression-Pets-Pets fight with you in combat-Pets can do basic shopping and selling for you-Online Multiplayer is fun-Low system requirements-Good graphics (not high tech, but nice to look at)-Can respec your skill points-Many different character builds-There's a class everyone will be interested in, despite only having four. And if you don't like them, find a mod that adds one that you do like!-Loads of mods to change your experience-Ravaging bosses with your friends is really fun-Loot is given out to you and you only; your friends don't see the loot that you see on the ground, but you can pick it up and drop it if you wish to give them the item.Cons:-NO SCYTHES. WTF MANG?! (Fo real doe, where did you put the scythes)-Pets are not really that useful; in combat they just basic attack your enemies unless you feed them fish, which can change them into a creature with better combat skills temporarily. Other than that, pets are just there for aesthetics.-Combat is not really skillful-Combat is repetitive, although not always boring-Story is a formality-Main quest related NPCs are forgettable even with voiced dialog-Vanilla inventory UI is just bad.-AI isn't too smart-The game is slightly overpriced (But I got it when it was on sale for 5 dollars hue hue hue u jelly bruh?)-With mods installed its kind of hard to find an online game room that is compatible with you (if the room leader doesn't have mod x active and you do have mod x active, you cannot see that room, at least as far as I'm aware)Overall, I'd say Torchlight II is worth buying, but wait for it to go on sale unless you have to play it right now/have extra cash laying around in your gold palace.**Disclaimer** I'm reviewing this game based almost entirely on my own likes and dislikes, not necessarily how it stacks up to other games in the same genre, which is probably bad but I haven't played many games like Torchlight II, Diablo, etc/don't give enough damns.

ry 28, 2016
												Torchlight's actual storyline and most major quests can be completed in ~15-20 hours. However, the extra content that takes more grinding is the real meat of this game. Acquiring end-game loot to make yourself a raidboss is the final destination. My experience with this game is that at first it's quite disorienting, however with more gameplay it gets better, but also becomes very robotic . I do like the graphics and the storyline of the game as well as the variety of different settings and monsters you face. However, if you don't like grinding this game may not be for you. I would recommend this game if it's on sale, but if it were bought for full price I don't think it's worth it.I like the fact that you can Co-op, however in co-op worlds the max amount of players is 4 and whatever you accomplish in that co-op world isn't translated over to your singleplayer, so it's best to keep quests finished in singleplayer first. My impression of the community is that there's a bunch of super dedicated players and keep to themselves a lot and if you're not dedicated you can't break the ice with them. Another awesome feature is that the workshop really brings out a whole new environment for the game. Extra classes, extra abilities,the workshops are a must visit if you want to experience this game fully.Some downsides do include that the combat interface/system isn't explained at first and you're just dropped in a place and you're expected to know how to fight. Maybe a tutorial at first wouldn't hurt. With this being said, the learning curve isn't actually that great if you've played any RPG before. There are 4 basic stats each helping a certain feature and beneficial for certain classes.In summary, I think this game has some great features, the main storyline replayability isn't that high, but the workshops and the extra after the storyline quest grinding will be what you spend most of your time on. I rate this game a good 8/10 for $5.49, maybe lower if it's going for $21.99.

er 10, 2015
												Coming from somebody that did play Diablo 2 back in the day (and wasn't as fond of it as other people), this game takes the typical frustrating aspects of that game and throws them out the window. While it's possible that Diablo 3 does some of these things as well, I'm afraid I haven't played that game yet. First, you can load up your pet with unwanted loot and send it back to town while in the middle of a dungeon to sell for you. Generally returning after two minutes. You can even have it purchase stuff in town for you, like potions or scrolls. It's so nice to not have to constantly port back to town to empty out my inventory. You also don't have to click on gold to pick it up. You just have to walk over it. I may never play Diablo 2 again after getting used to such a nice feature. You get a hotbar for skills. You don't even need to have potions take up space on it because pressing Z or X automatically uses your best healing or mana potion. So I can press 1 for a firestorm, press 2 for fire pillars, press 3 to summon a ghost, etc. It kinda feels like playing an MMO. You can find ambiguous spells on any character that you can have four of equiped at any time, offering some variety into your gameplay. Like a spell that summons a horde of zombies, or a simple fireball, or a passive buff to your EXP and gold earned. The really cool part is that your pet also gets four spell slots and will use any spells automatically when you get into a fight and they're off cooldown. I have my pet set to summon two hordes of zombies AND some skeleton archers, with a passive spell that increases his damage and shortens the time it takes for him to get back from town. There's so much this game does right that it makes me kinda disappointed that the devs have moved on to other projects and don't plan to update Torchlight 2 anymore. But still, the game has easy intigration built in for the modding community. Totally recommended.

r 8, 2014
												Experience of playing as 2-handed engy on Veteran Act III: "wtf just hit me I'm dead"This game is good. From the soothing string music to humorous weapon descriptions, there is a lot to see and play.  Loot drops rate are just right. Game mechanics are tight and well done (aside from the armor system) You don't have to go crazy on grinding for a proper weapon. Unique-tier weapons look pretty cool and have great descriptions to boot. Their damage and stats also fit your requirements for reasonably long, unlike that one FPS where your purple-rarity gun does ♥♥♥♥ damage 2-3 levels later. Apples to oranges. I don't care.The inclusion of "Arcane Stats", where you can see your actual damage output, proc chances, actual armor after bonuses factor in, etc, is really, really useful. This helps a lot in planning your build, and you don't have to do convoluted calculations to find your optimum loadout, and try to figure out whether a particular bonus is additive, multiplicative, applied post-multiplication, blahblah.The UI is very well built, comparing gear is easy, organizing items is easy, weapon damage is listed in DPS (honestly, why the hell not).However, when it comes to the really-high difficulties (NG+ Veteran, NG Elite, Mapworks), the armor system starts to show some bad problems if you play a tanking class. Armor damage reduction is calculated point-by-point rather as a percentage. Meaning if you have 800 armor, you will reduce an incoming attack by 800 damage. To play a serious build during Elite NG++ levels, you will have to farm for damage reduction socketables if you plan on consistently not dying when a mob so much as breathes on you.To quote Cthon from the TL2 forums:"Armor is basically meaningless. Not only is it badly outscaled by monster damage, but its effectiveness is also reduced by any damage reduction you have. To be as charitable as possible to armor, it's reasonably effective early on before monster damage scaling really gets going. A player who only did the first playthrough and did not do mapworks or NG+ might not encounter very many situations where no feasible amount of armor makes a meaningful difference."^This applies to anything above normal difficulty.Again, nobody cares about the story. Play on veteran mode if you've played RPGs before, normal is kinda easy.

												I don't play games 24/7 but I must say I was waiting day by day for the release of the new Torchlight, since I enjoyed the original so much. Forget the story and any role-playing, this is all about shooting monsters with an increasingly complex and bewildering array of weapons and skills. There may be only four classes but there are many ways to build each one, thanks to the enormous skills tree. Levelling is fast and furious in the beginning, but I do feel things bog down once Act III comes around. It can take a long time to improve your character, and I found I stuck with armor and weapons I had found a long time ago. With skills only incrementally improving, this is a bit dull. But still! there are always new monsters to kill. And I haven't even played multi yet. By the way, I recommend Veteran difficulty for the right blend of challenges.

Então, sempre tenho muito a falar, mas dessa vez, irei dar uma breve resumida do que se trata o game.Não tem como falar de quaisquer jogos no estilo de RPG, sem mencionar o grande e poderoso Diablo. Pois bem, esse jogo aqui, em alguns quesitos, bate de forma relevante o Diablo 3, jogo mais atual da franquia. Como por exemplo o preço, Torchlight 2 é muito, mas muito parecido com Diablo 3 e o preço é bem mais baixo. Também ganha do Diablo no quesito de que não necessita de internet 24hrs para jogar, já que o jogo dispõe do modo offline que pode ser totalmente divertido, embora também tenha o modo online, bom para jogar com amigos, porque se você não tiver amigos para jogar numa party, dificilmente vai achar alguem sozinho nos servidores, porque o jogo está praticamente sem ninguém jogando os modos onlines. Se tiver interesse no jogo, pode comprar que não irá se arrepender, mas não tenha a intenção de jogar online, a menos que já tenha amigos para isso.Torchlight 2 tem um mundo gigantesco para ser explorado, com milhares de missões primárias e outras toneladas de missões secundárias. A ação é muito frenética com MUITOS inimigos dentro do mapa, não só nas INSTANCES. Dificilmente irá achar apenas um monstro numa area do mapa, você irá achar muitos e a matança, nesse caso, é frenética.Por fim, o que se espera de um verdadeiro jogo de RPG? Muito conteúdo de personalização? Torchlight 2 tem! Classes de personagens criativas? Confere também! Milhares de itens e sets? Torchlight 2 também tem! Cara, esse jogo é perfeito. Tá esperando o que pra fazer a melhor aquisição de um jogo RPG da sua vida? Você vai ficar extremamente viciado. Embora eu tenha poucas horas aqui no jogo da steam, acho que já tenho mais de 200 horas no pirata, (fora da steam, quando jogava a uns aninhos atrás).Esse jogo, é o jogo que de todos os outros que ja joguei, é o que mais recomendo. Garanto pra você que se comprar, não vai querer sair desse mundo nunca mais. Vale comprar em toda época do ano, com promoção, sem promoção, dar de presente pros amigos, não importa, o que vale é expandir esse jogo pra todo mundo. Garanto que o investimento gasto nesse game, tanto para si mesmo como para presentear alguém, será muito bem feito.

r 8, 2014
												Experience of playing as 2-handed engy on Veteran Act III: "wtf just hit me I'm dead"This game is good. From the soothing string music to humorous weapon descriptions, there is a lot to see and play.  Loot drops rate are just right. Game mechanics are tight and well done (aside from the armor system) You don't have to go crazy on grinding for a proper weapon. Unique-tier weapons look pretty cool and have great descriptions to boot. Their damage and stats also fit your requirements for reasonably long, unlike that one FPS where your purple-rarity gun does ♥♥♥♥ damage 2-3 levels later. Apples to oranges. I don't care.The inclusion of "Arcane Stats", where you can see your actual damage output, proc chances, actual armor after bonuses factor in, etc, is really, really useful. This helps a lot in planning your build, and you don't have to do convoluted calculations to find your optimum loadout, and try to figure out whether a particular bonus is additive, multiplicative, applied post-multiplication, blahblah.The UI is very well built, comparing gear is easy, organizing items is easy, weapon damage is listed in DPS (honestly, why the hell not).However, when it comes to the really-high difficulties (NG+ Veteran, NG Elite, Mapworks), the armor system starts to show some bad problems if you play a tanking class. Armor damage reduction is calculated point-by-point rather as a percentage. Meaning if you have 800 armor, you will reduce an incoming attack by 800 damage. To play a serious build during Elite NG++ levels, you will have to farm for damage reduction socketables if you plan on consistently not dying when a mob so much as breathes on you.To quote Cthon from the TL2 forums:"Armor is basically meaningless. Not only is it badly outscaled by monster damage, but its effectiveness is also reduced by any damage reduction you have. To be as charitable as possible to armor, it's reasonably effective early on before monster damage scaling really gets going. A player who only did the first playthrough and did not do mapworks or NG+ might not encounter very many situations where no feasible amount of armor makes a meaningful difference."^This applies to anything above normal difficulty.Again, nobody cares about the story. Play on veteran mode if you've played RPGs before, normal is kinda easy.

												This is a pretty fun game in the vein of "Diablo": a good, solid RPG/Action title with a skill tree where you move your character around and click the jibbers out of various people, monsters, and so forth. You don't always get the best price on things, but hey - what do you expect out of a bulldog/ferret/spider/whatever-the-heck you decided to pick? It also sometimes helps in combat, so it's not useless.Overall, I say this game is a sturdy 7.5/10. If you enjoyed the first two DIABLO games, definitely buy it, and if you find it on sale, then what are you waiting for? Get that game!

content:
7, 2014
												Crowborn's Review of Torchlight II-Ever since I was a boy, and got my hands on Diablo 1, I have been a fan of the hack-n-slash game-genre. Something about the game strung a cord inside of me, and I played it almost non-stop for years. Same with the sequel - it kept me busy through highschool and sane in the awkward years following when I was rampaging through life, trying to figure out what the 'eck I wanted to do. And so arrived the highly anticipated 3rd installment of the Diablo genre - to lackluster reviews. I picked it up immediately of course, but I were never able to enjoy it. It just seemed off to me, seemed strange, like an orange growing on an apple-tree, trying to fit in with the smooth green skinned fellas around it. But for me it failed at the deceit, and I put down the game after playing it for only a few months. Dissapointed and bereft of one of my favourite genres, I started looking around for substitutes. That's when I heard about Torchlight II.I had noticed the series before, but for some reason never gotten around to trying it out. It was supposed to be a fairly good diablo-clone, and while I liked the genre, it wasn't until one of my dear steam-friends gifted me the game, that I actually managed to sit down and play it. I felt obliged to, so to say. And my were I pleasantly surprised!Torchlight II is a really well made game. From the steam-punkish world, cross the interesting skill-sets, to the actio-packed maps - this game just breathes fun game design. Granted, the game is 'very' much a Diablo-clone, and anyone who ever played those games will immediately find everything intimately familiar. But that's not a bad thing. In fact, I find it darned good. I didn't have to read a bible of game-guides before daring to venture out in the the world of Torchlight, and hack and slash my way through the first pack of monsters I came across. It granted me immediate satisfaction and loads of fun.It feels to me like the devs of this game did right, what the guys at Blizz did wrong. Torchlight II follows to a point the tried and true old recipe of hack-n-slash. They don't try to reinvent or alter the genre, but instead stick to what works and 'has' worked for the last two decades. You got your attribute-points, your skill-points, random loot, runes and enchantments to upgrade your gear, rewarding exploration, and a story-line that doesn't distract you from your dungeon-delving fun.The game hearkens back to the good old days, and gives the players exactly what they expected - and a little more. It deserves a top grade, but due to an at times non-transparent stat-system and unbalanced characters, I have to subtract a few points. I give it:8.5/10

												Enough of the Diablo 2 comparisons - the genre has evolved enough to......wait....ha ha who the hell am I kidding. Torchlight 2 is something like Antje Traue; it's silently risen to the apex of its genre (or in Traue's case, she's climbed over the plastic American bimbos from Hollywood and has become the most attractive woman in the universe). I was never too interested in the first TL game, but this was mostly because I was ingesting too much morphine and I had a serious porn addiction. What immediately grabbed me about its sequel, however, was its foundation in the Steamworks system. It's so simple to download and install mods, and while it's technically limited to ten active at any one time, it's quite easy to combine mods in the GUTS editor. As of the end of 2013, I really have no idea why any developer wouldn't want this implemented in their gaming environment. It extends playability by an infinite margin, and the only excuse I could think of from "big-time" publishers is that they really couldn't give a ♥♥♥♥ if people play their game - they only care about sales. (Insert TORtanic joke here.) But okay, enough soapboxing. Is it worth buying? If you're even remotely intrigued by the isometric hack-n-slash model, this game is a godsend (remark about religion). It's visceral, bloody, fast-paced, and there are so many different ways to play. I don't remember how many vanilla classes there are, but if you get off your soggy ♥♥♥ for two seconds you can find about twenty new classes in the workshop. There is so much to offer in this package, and you should buy it. 10/10 would play again

												I was headed towards a dungeon to complete a quest, ended up exploring the whole map, killed all the mobs, searched for the golden key to open the golden chest, went through a random portal which reserved me a side mission and finally started the dungeon. Seriously you won't see the time pass in this game, there is a lot to do. Pros:-Interesting bosses/monsters.-Complex itemization (many stats, enchantments, etc).-Multiple things to do (quests (dungeons, secret rooms, bosses), sidequests (mazes, mini bosses, etc) and other random stuff to do (fishing, gambling,etc). -Fun game to play with friends (if you're playing with multiple friends, play on elite or else it will be too easy).-Good combat system. In general, you can't simply spam click to clear mobs, the game pushes you to dodge abilities, manage your mana pool and react to different scenarios (use abilities to trap big guys, use your escape ability to..well escape,etc). Cons:-The story is bad, this is definietly not the game to play for its story. To be honest, I stopped caring about the story very early on.-Can get a bit repetitive. -Okay character custimization (character creation allows you to play very little with your character's features).8/10, great game to pick up when it goes on sale.
